awd_titl_txt: FRG: Collaborative Research: Algebra and Geometry Behind Link Homology
awd_abstract_narration:
The Hecke algebra and its generalizations are central objects in modern representation theory. They naturally appear in number theory, representation theory, algebraic geometry, and even low-dimensional topology. A categorification of the Hecke algebra was used to define a new topological invariant of knots and links, known as HOMFLY-PT homology. However, it is extremely difficult to compute this invariant from the definition. The project is focused on understanding the algebraic, geometric, and combinatorial structure of link homology and categorified Hecke algebras, with the goal of unifying, deepening, and clarifying connections between these concepts.

Recent progress strongly indicates a connection between the HOMFLY-PT homology and algebraic geometry of the Hilbert scheme of points on the plane, a central object in modern algebraic geometry and geometric representation theory.  In this collaborative project, the investigators plan to compare and unify different approaches to the study of this connection and to develop the fundamental understanding of the relation between the category of Soergel bimodules and the Hilbert scheme. They also plan to provide an algebro-geometric construction of HOMFLY-PT homology and to understand its relation to the combinatorics of Macdonald polynomials.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The project sought to develop a number of mathematical incarnations of knot invariants (i.e. numbers, polynomials, or more complicated quantities that one uses in order to distinguish knots from each other). These include notions from several fields of mathematics, such as matrix factorizations, Soergel bimodules, Hilbert schemes and affine Springer fibers. One of our main goals, and I believe also one of the main positive outcomes of this project, was to bridge the various constructions of knot invariants mentioned above. For example, Oblomkov and Rozansky bridged matrix factorizations and Soergel bimodules, through a wide-reaching series of very deep (and quite numerous) papers. In recent work, Gorsky, Kivinen and Oblomkov connected affine Springer filbers with Hilbert schemes on a punctured plane, thus providing another link in the framework above. Finally, one last example is a recent paper of Gorsky and Negut, which bridges Hilbert schemes and the elliptic Hall algebra, with a notion known as the trace of the affine Hecke category (which is where knots on a torus, or donut, "live" in a certain mathematical sense). These connections have not only helped to shed light on an interesting and rapidly developing field, but they have provided the potential for even more connections to be established with other fields, thus allowing the theory of knot invariants to permeate deeper in mathematics.
